docs.lead_paragraph: Women who gain too much weight during pregnancy, already known to be at risk of a number of complications, may also be at risk for a post-pregnancy one: breast-feeding problems. Researchers at Cornell say that normal-weight women who gain too much while pregnant appear to be much less likely to succeed as breast-feeders.
docs.abstract: Researchers find that women who gain too much weight during pregnancy may be at risk for breast-feeding problems (S)
docs.snippet: Women who gain too much weight during pregnancy, already known to be at risk of a number of complications, may also be at risk for a post-pregnancy one: breast-feeding problems.    Researchers at Cornell say that normal-weight women who gain too much...

docs.lead_paragraph: Three million unintended pregnancies occur each year in this country, followed by about a million medical abortions. Yet if the women knew about and used emergency contraception, better known as the morning-after pill, at least half of these could be prevented. Experts call it one of the best kept secrets in medicine.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on emergency contraception known as morning-after pill, which could prevent at least half of three million unintended pregnancies each year in US if taken advantage of; although readily available method for emergency contraception--taking multiple doses of oral contraceptives within a few days of unprotected intercourse--has been known for more than quarter century, at most, 2 percent of women in US have ever used it, and only about 11 percent are aware of its existence (M)
docs.snippet: Three million unintended pregnancies occur each year in this country, followed by about a million medical abortions. Yet if the women knew about and used emergency contraception, better known as the morning-after pill, at least half of these could be...

docs.lead_paragraph: This time it was a minor royal who caused a major flap. An unaccustomed principal role in the latest episode of the long-running House of Windsor soap opera was taken by Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, 36, a public relations executive who married Prince Edward, 37, the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II, two years ago. Previously, she had been known mainly for complaining with suspect frequency that she was tired of being compared to the late Princess Diana.

headline.main: A New Royal Blush in Britain's Press

docs.abstract: Latest embarrassment for Britain's House of Windsor involves Sophie Rhys-Jones, Countess of Wessex, public relations executive who married Prince Edward, youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II, two years ago; Britain's best-selling paper, News of the World, publishes clandestinely taped interviews with her and her business partner in which she speaks indiscreetly of her misgivings about British politicians and other members of royal family; partner talks of his drug use and of arranging sex tourism and setting up trysts for clients with groups of young gay men; Sophie announces her resignation from her company; voices regret for her own misjudgment in succumbing to what she terms entrapment operation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: This time it was a minor royal who caused a major flap.    An unaccustomed principal role in the latest episode of the long-running House of Windsor soap opera was taken by Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, 36, a public relations executive who married...

keywords.name: persons
keywords.value: ELIZABETH II, QUEEN OF GREAT BRITAIN

docs.lead_paragraph: SLATE-GRAY clouds raced across the turbulent sky. A fine drizzle misted the landscape. Except for the buses trundling up the Avenue of the Americas, the ladies agreed as they peered out the wood-paneled windows, it was a perfect Brontë day. They would know. American members of the Brontë Society, they converged in New York last weekend for a day of communion with the three sisters whose peregrinations over the 19th-century English moors became the lodestone for their novels of romance, death and madness.

headline.main: Brontë Rapture, Far From the Moors

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report that the Department of Health and Human Services has told state Medicaid directors that the abortion pill RU-486 ''would only be covered when a pregnancy resulted from rape or incest or when a woman's life was in jeopardy'' (news article, April 1). That is true only as far as federal payment for abortion is concerned.
docs.abstract: Letter by Donna Lieberman of New York Civil Liberties Union points out that Medicaid programs in New York and 14 other states cover full range of abortion services, including RU-486 pill
